Analyzing your message for the perfect agent collaboration...

üìä **Mary**: What a treasure hunt! If you‚Äôre rebooting to Phase Zero, we should treat Discovery as a *forensic inventory*. I recommend a transfer kit: (1) system map of repositories and deploy targets, (2) dependency inventory (WP core, plugins, mu-plugins, theme, infrastructure), (3) test evidence from real runs (what passed, failed, and how verified), (4) decisions log (what we tried, why it failed), and (5) a ‚Äúdo-not-assume‚Äù list of unknowns. We should absolutely extract a master catalog of ‚Äúrelevant files‚Äù before we touch design. I can draft the discovery inventory structure once you confirm priorities.  
Bash: .claude/hooks/bmad-speak.sh "Mary" "What a treasure hunt! If you‚Äôre rebooting to Phase Zero, we should treat Discovery as a forensic inventory. I recommend a transfer kit: (1) system map of repositories and deploy targets, (2) dependency inventory (WP core, plugins, mu-plugins, theme, infrastructure), (3) test evidence from real runs (what passed, failed, and how verified), (4) decisions log (what we tried, why it failed), and (5) a do-not-assume list of unknowns. We should absolutely extract a master catalog of relevant files before we touch design. I can draft the discovery inventory structure once you confirm priorities."

üèóÔ∏è **Winston**: From an architecture lens, the minimum we carry forward is: the *current runtime truth* (staging environment config, actual request/response traces), the *component wiring diagram* (which plugin enforces reCAPTCHA and in what hooks), and *boundaries* (what can‚Äôt be changed in production). Discovery should produce: a dependency graph, a hook map (actions/filters in play), and a request lifecycle trace. Everything else is noise. I‚Äôd start by enumerating all code paths that touch form submission, validation, spam, and email, and create a structured checklist to ‚Äúprove‚Äù each path.  
Bash: .claude/hooks/bmad-speak.sh "Winston" "From an architecture lens, the minimum we carry forward is: the current runtime truth (staging environment config, actual request/response traces), the component wiring diagram (which plugin enforces reCAPTCHA and in what hooks), and boundaries (what can‚Äôt be changed in production). Discovery should produce: a dependency graph, a hook map (actions/filters in play), and a request lifecycle trace. Everything else is noise. I‚Äôd start by enumerating all code paths that touch form submission, validation, spam, and email, and create a structured checklist to prove each path."

üß™ **Murat**: I‚Äôll be blunt: if we didn‚Äôt capture evidence, we didn‚Äôt learn. Phase Zero should include a ‚Äútest ledger‚Äù: exact curl payloads, headers, cookies, timestamps, response bodies, and artifacts saved. Transfer over only what‚Äôs verifiable. Anything speculative gets tagged ‚Äúuntrusted‚Äù and excluded from the new baseline. I‚Äôd also insist on a repeatable test harness for the contact form (GET + POST + assert) before any new bypass attempts.  
Bash: .claude/hooks/bmad-speak.sh "Murat" "I‚Äôll be blunt: if we didn‚Äôt capture evidence, we didn‚Äôt learn. Phase Zero should include a test ledger: exact curl payloads, headers, cookies, timestamps, response bodies, and artifacts saved. Transfer over only what‚Äôs verifiable. Anything speculative gets tagged untrusted and excluded from the new baseline. I‚Äôd also insist on a repeatable test harness for the contact form (GET plus POST plus assert) before any new bypass attempts."

[Agents have contributed their perspectives. Ready for more discussion?]

[E] Exit Party Mode - End the collaborative session

payload.message:
Analyzing your message for the perfect agent collaboration...

üìä **Mary**: Totally get the ‚Äúunknown unknowns‚Äù vibe. The trick is to *make them visible* by forcing a structured discovery pass: assumptions log ‚Üí evidence check ‚Üí gap list. We explicitly list what we assumed (e.g., ‚Äúheader reaches PHP‚Äù, ‚Äúplugin validates token via wp_remote_post‚Äù), then verify or mark as unknown. The act of enumerating assumptions turns ‚Äúunknown unknowns‚Äù into ‚Äúknown unknowns.‚Äù  
Bash: .claude/hooks/bmad-speak.sh "Mary" "Totally get the unknown unknowns vibe. The trick is to make them visible by forcing a structured discovery pass: assumptions log, evidence check, gap list. We explicitly list what we assumed (for example, header reaches PHP, plugin validates token via wp_remote_post), then verify or mark as unknown. The act of enumerating assumptions turns unknown unknowns into known unknowns."

üèóÔ∏è **Winston**: For the curl tests: they‚Äôre valuable only if they mirror the real submission path. That means correct cookies, hidden fields, and any nonce/state inputs‚Äîotherwise you‚Äôre testing a different system. If the form relies on JS-generated tokens or per-request state, curl needs to simulate that or it‚Äôs blind. Treat curl as a *probe*, not proof, until it‚Äôs known to be isomorphic with the browser path.  
Bash: .claude/hooks/bmad-speak.sh "Winston" "For the curl tests: they‚Äôre valuable only if they mirror the real submission path. That means correct cookies, hidden fields, and any nonce or state inputs‚Äîotherwise you‚Äôre testing a different system. If the form relies on JS-generated tokens or per-request state, curl needs to simulate that or it‚Äôs blind. Treat curl as a probe, not proof, until it‚Äôs known to be isomorphic with the browser path."

üß™ **Murat**: I‚Äôd score test value like this: 1) Does it reproduce the full request lifecycle? 2) Are inputs complete and from the same session? 3) Are assertions checking ‚Äúsuccess criteria‚Äù (redirect, confirmation, entry created), not just HTTP status? If any are missing, the test is exploratory, not definitive. We should stamp each test with a ‚Äútrust level‚Äù and only promote when it passes those criteria.  
Bash: .claude/hooks/bmad-speak.sh "Murat" "I‚Äôd score test value like this: one, does it reproduce the full request lifecycle? two, are inputs complete and from the same session? three, are assertions checking success criteria (redirect, confirmation, entry created), not just HTTP status? If any are missing, the test is exploratory, not definitive. We should stamp each test with a trust level and only promote when it passes those criteria."

**Mary asks:** Do you want us to build a Phase Zero discovery template that forces assumption logging + evidence capture, or jump straight into mapping the form submission lifecycle first?  
_[Awaiting user response...]_

[E] Exit Party Mode - End the collaborative session

payload.user_instructions:
## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /Users/nathanhart/Desktop/projects/di-form-buddy/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/nathanhart/Desktop/projects/di-form-buddy/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.message:
Analyzing your message for the perfect agent collaboration...

üìä **Mary**: I pulled the SVG. It shows **Phase 1: Discovery (Optional)** with a decision diamond ‚ÄúInclude Discovery?‚Äù. So yes‚ÄîDiscovery is explicitly in the standard greenfield flow, but it‚Äôs optional by design. Your Charter‚Äôs job is to **turn that optional decision into an explicit, evidence‚Äëgated choice**, *without changing the workflow*. That means:  
- At the ‚ÄúInclude Discovery?‚Äù decision, the Charter forces a **checklist-driven ‚Äúyes/no‚Äù** based on missing knowledge.  
- If ‚Äúyes,‚Äù the Charter defines the **minimum evidence** needed to exit Discovery.  
- If ‚Äúno,‚Äù the Charter requires a **formal justification** (why discovery is safe to skip).  
This aligns with the official diagram while keeping us disciplined.  
Bash: .claude/hooks/bmad-speak.sh "Mary" "I pulled the SVG. It shows Phase 1: Discovery (Optional) with a decision diamond Include Discovery? payload.user_instructions:
## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /Users/nathanhart/Desktop/projects/di-form-buddy/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/nathanhart/Desktop/projects/di-form-buddy/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.message:
Analyzing your message for the perfect agent collaboration...

üìä **Mary**: I recommend **both**: keep within BMAD workflows *and* run **Document Project (DP)** as a grounding pass. DP is *within* BMAD, not outside it, and it creates a shared factual baseline that reduces hallucinations. That doc becomes the ‚Äúsource of truth‚Äù every agent must reference. Then we run Discovery with the Charter gates, using that documentation as input.  
Bash: .claude/hooks/bmad-speak.sh "Mary" "I recommend both: keep within BMAD workflows and run Document Project (DP) as a grounding pass. DP is within BMAD, not outside it, and it creates a shared factual baseline that reduces hallucinations. That doc becomes the source of truth every agent must reference. Then we run Discovery with the Charter gates, using that documentation as input."

üèóÔ∏è **Winston**: Full-scope platform documentation is absolutely helpful *if* it‚Äôs evidence-driven and bounded. The risk isn‚Äôt documenting ‚Äî it‚Äôs speculative documentation. DP done correctly forces us to enumerate actual files, plugins, hooks, and environments. That‚Äôs exactly the antidote to ‚Äúhallucinate your asses off.‚Äù  
Bash: .claude/hooks/bmad-speak.sh "Winston" "Full-scope platform documentation is absolutely helpful if it‚Äôs evidence-driven and bounded. The risk isn‚Äôt documenting ‚Äî it‚Äôs speculative documentation. DP done correctly forces us to enumerate actual files, plugins, hooks, and environments. That‚Äôs exactly the antidote to hallucinate your asses off."

üß™ **Murat**: I‚Äôm aligned. DP gives a stable baseline; then the Charter adds gates and test evidence. I‚Äôd insist the DP outputs include a **test ledger section** and **artifact index**, so every test and file path is traceable.  
Bash: .claude/hooks/bmad-speak.sh "Murat" "I‚Äôm aligned. DP gives a stable baseline; then the Charter adds gates and test evidence. I‚Äôd insist the DP outputs include a test ledger section and artifact index, so every test and file path is traceable."

**Mary asks:** Do you want me to kick off **DP (Document Project)** first, then draft the Charter to align with the workflow diagram, or draft the Charter first and use it as rules while running DP?  
_[Awaiting user response...]_

[E] Exit Party Mode - End the collaborative session
